STATE OF MICHIGAN
DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
GRETCHEN WHITMER
LANS ING
ELIZABETH HERTEL
GOVERNOR DIRECTOR
P.O. BOX 30650 • LANSING, MICHIGAN 48909
www.michigan.gov • (517) 335-1980
February 6, 2025
Ciara Johnson
Wayne County DHHS – North Central
8625 Greenfield Rd,
Detroit, MI, 48228-2224
Re: License #: CP820201495
Dear Ms. Johnson:
Attached is the Interim Inspection Report for the above referenced agency completed on
12/6/2024. Due to the violations of applicable licensing rules, a written corrective action
plan is required. The corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and
must include the following:
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action plan.
• Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action may result.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager Rorie Dodge-Pifer at 517-899-6024.
.

Sincerely,
Lonia Perry Calloway, Licensing Consultant
Enclosure
.
2

MICHIGAN DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
DIVISION OF CHILD WELFARE LICENSING
INTERIM INSPECTION REPORT
I. IDENTIFYING INFORMATION
License #: CP820201495
Licensee Group Organization: Michigan Department of Health and Human
Services
Licensee Designee: Demetrius LuJuan Starling
Chief Administrator: Ciara Johnson
Name of Agency: WAYNE COUNTY DHHS - NORTHCENTRAL
Agency Address: 8625 GREENFIELD RD
DETROIT, MI 48228-2224
Agency Telephone #: 3138521709
Original Issuance Date: 09/20/1993
Service Types: Certify foster homes for license, Evaluate
Applicants for adoption, Place children for
adoption, Place children in foster home,
Supervise Independent Living
1

II. METHODS OF INSPECTION
A. Consultant
Date(s) of On-site Inspection: 11/18, 11/19, 11/20, 11/21/, 12/4, 12/6-2024
Total No. Of No. of
Records Records
Reviewed
Current licensed foster homes 96 8
Homes pending licensure 21 4
Foster homes closed since the last inspection 24 3
Foster homes borrowed since the last inspection 56 6
Special Investigations in foster homes since last inspection 44 7

in foster care since last inspection 0 0
Incidents of substantiated corporal punishment in foster care
since last inspection 2 2
Children receiving direct foster care case management
(placement in foster homes, parental home,
relative homes, CCI, hospital, etc.) 355 8
Children discharged from care during this period 48 6
Youth in independent living placement 0 0
Youth discharged from an independent living placement
since the last inspection 0 0
Applicants approved for adoption since the last inspection N/A N/A
Applicants denied for adoption since the last inspection N/A N/A

Open child adoption cases N/A N/A

More than a year 58 7

2

B. Analyst
Total No. No. Visited
Licensed foster homes 96 5
Unlicensed relative homes 72 4
Number of persons interviewed:
Foster Parents 5
Foster Children 9
Relatives 4
Others (identify person interviewed by role) 0
III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
The agency is in compliance with all applicable rules and statutes except for the following:
CPA Rule 400.12212 Personnel records.
(3) The personnel record must contain both of the
following:
(a) A written evaluation of a staff member's performance
within a probationary period or not later than 6 months
after the staff member assumes his or her current
responsibilities. After the initial evaluation, a written
evaluation must be conducted every 12 months.
Three of 13 new employee records reviewed did not show compliance:
• One record showed the employee's probationary evaluation due by 4/6/2024
was completed late on 4/15/2024.
• A second record showed the employee's probationary evaluation due by
7/14/2024 was completed late on 7/17/2024.
• A third record showed the employee's probationary evaluation due by
5/18/2024 was completed late on 5/23/2024.
Repeat Violation Established:
Renewal Inspection 2023, CAP approved 1/8/2024.
Interim Inspection 2022, CAP approved 2/14/2023.
2

CPA Rule 400.12324 Reevaluation.
(2) The annual reevaluation must include a determination
and assessment of all the following:
(b) Family functioning and interrelationships as
determined by observation of, and interviews with, each
member of the household and each social service worker
who has had children placed in the home during the last
licensing period.
Four of six open foster home records reviewed did not show compliance:
• The record either did not show a summary of the worker’s interview or
observation with all household members, or did not indicate the strengths and
weaknesses of the foster parent as reported by the foster parent and worker.
CPA Rule 400.12324 Reevaluation.
(8) An agency shall complete a reevaluation and make a
licensing recommendation to the department at least 15
calendar days before the expiration date of the foster
home license.
One of six open foster home records reviewed showed the licensing
recommendation was submitted on 1/26/2024, which was after the foster home's
1/19/2024 licensing expiration date.
Repeat Violation Established:
Interim Inspection 2022, CAP approved 2/14/2023.
CPA Rule 400.12327 Special evaluation.
(5) Within 15 days of the conclusion of the evaluation, an
agency shall complete a written report that includes all
the following information:
(c) Dates and places of contacts, names of persons
interviewed, and names of the interviewers. If children
are interviewed, their last names may not be included in
the report.
One of seven special evaluation records reviewed did not show documentation of all
persons interviewed related to one of the allegations.
3

Repeat Violation Established:
Interim Inspection, 2022, CAP approved 2/14/2023.
CPA Rule 400.12405 Change of placement.
(5) If an agency is no longer providing services to the
child in a foster home, then both the following must be
documented before a change in placement:
(a) A summary of the services provided during care up to
the time of the change in placement and the needs that
remain to be met.
Four of six closed foster child records reviewed did not show documentation of (a)
as required by the rule; the information was left blank.
Repeat Violation Established:
Renewal Inspection 2023, CAP approved 1/8/2024.
CPA Rule 400.12405 Change of placement.
(5) If an agency is no longer providing services to the
child in a foster home, then both the following must be
documented before a change in placement:
(b) Provision for any continuing services.
Four of six closed foster child records reviewed did not show documentation of (b)
as required by the rule; the information was left blank.
Repeat Violation Established:
Renewal Inspection 2023, CAP approved 1/8/2024.
CPA Rule 400.12413 Medical and dental care policy.
(1) An agency's medical and dental care policy must,
include all the following:
(c) A physical examination for each child as follows,
unless a greater frequency is medically indicated:
(i) A comprehensive medical examination, including a
behavioral/mental health and trauma screening, within
30 calendar days from the date the child entered into an
4

out-of-home placement, regardless of the date of the last
physical examination.
Four of eight open foster child records reviewed did not show compliance:
• Three records showed the child's trauma screening due by 5/5/2024,
10/4/2024, and 11/12/2024 were completed late on 6/6/2024, 10/4/2024; and
12/7/2024 respectively.
• A fourth record showed the child’s trauma screening due by 9/26/2024 was
completed late on 12/13/2024. This child’s medical exam due by 9/26/2024
was not documented.
Repeat Violation Established:
Renewal Inspection 2023, CAP approved 1/8/2024.
CPA Rule 400.12413 Medical and dental care policy.
(1) An agency's medical and dental care policy must,
include all the following:
(e) A dental examination must be completed within 3
months before entry into foster care or an initial dental
examination must be completed not more than 90
calendar days after entry into a foster care out-of-home
placement. A child entering foster care under 1 year of
age must have an initial dental exam within 3 months of
his or her first birthday.
One of eight open foster child records reviewed showed the child's dental due by
1/11/2024 was completed late on 2/29/2024.
Repeat Violation Established:
Renewal Inspection 2023, CAP approved 1/8/2024.
CPA Rule 400.12417 Foster parent information.
(1) An agency shall provide a foster parent with all the
following information before the placement or
replacement of a child:
(c) Available known information about the child's health.
Three of eight open foster child records reviewed did not show documentation of (c)
as required by the rule. One of these records also did not show documentation of
(c), as required by the rule related to the child’s replacement on 11/8/2024.
5

Repeat Violation Established
Renewal Inspection 2023, CAP approved 1/8/2024.
CPA Rule 400.12417 Foster parent information.
(1) An agency shall provide a foster parent with all the
following information before the placement or
replacement of a child:
(d) Any known history of abuse or neglect of the child.
Three of eight open foster child records reviewed did not show documentation of (d)
as required by the rule. One of these records also did not show documentation of
(d), as required by the rule related to the child’s replacement on 11/8/2024.
Repeat Violation Established
Renewal Inspection 2023, CAP approved 1/8/2024.
CPA Rule 400.12417 Foster parent information.
(1) An agency shall provide a foster parent with all the
following information before the placement or
replacement of a child:
(e) All known emotional and psychological factors
relating to the care of the child.
Three of eight open foster child records reviewed did not show documentation of (e)
as required by the rule. One of these records also did not show documentation of
(e), as required by the rule related to the child’s replacement on 11/8/2024.
Repeat Violation Established:
Renewal Inspection 2023, CAP approved 1/8/2024.
CPA Rule 400.12417 Foster parent information.
(1) An agency shall provide a foster parent with all the
following information before the placement or
replacement of a child:
(f) All known behaviors of the child.
6

Three of eight open foster child records reviewed did not show documentation of (f)
as required by the rule. One of these records also did not show documentation of (f),
as required by the rule related to the child’s replacement on 11/8/2024.
Repeat Violation Established:
Renewal Inspection 2023, CAP approved 1/8/2024.
CPA Rule 400.12418 Development of service plans.
(2) An agency shall complete written service plans for
each child and parent or parents, as follows:
(a) Within 30 calendar days from removal from the home.
In one of eight open foster child records reviewed the child's 3/27/2024-4/27/2024
Initial Service Plan (ISP) was completed 7 days late on 5/3/2024.
Repeat Violation Established:
Renewal Inspection 2023, CAP approved 1/8/2024.
CPA Rule 400.12418 Development of service plans.
(2) An agency shall complete written service plans for
each child and parent or parents, as follows:
(b) Within 120 calendar days after the initial removal and
at least once every 90 calendar days thereafter.
Two of eight open foster child records reviewed did not show compliance:
• One child's 11/29/2023-2/26/2024 Updated Service Plan (USP) was
completed 42 days late on 4/9/2024.
• A second child’s 7/18/2024-10/15/2025 USP completed 19 days late on
11/4/2024.
Repeat Violation Established:
Renewal Inspection 2023, CAP approved 1/8/2024.
CPA Rule 400.12418 Development of service plans.
(5) An agency shall involve the child's parent or parents
and the foster parents in the development of service
plans to enable the parent or parents and foster parents
to understand the plan for the child and the parents' and
the foster parent's role in assisting the agency in carrying
7

out the plan. An agency shall give a copy to and review
the parent-agency treatment plan with the parent or
parents and foster parents. The agency must inform the
parent or parents and foster parent that the information
in the parent-agency treatment plan and any other
information about the child and the child's family is
confidential.
Five of eight open foster child records reviewed did not show compliance:
• One record showed the child’s 11/29/2023-2/26/2024 USP treatment plan
was not signed by the birth parent until 12/10/2024.
• A second record showed the child’s 3/27/2024-4/25/2024 ISP treatment plan;
and 4/26/2024-7/24/2024 USP treatment plan was signed by the caregiver,
but not dated. I could not discern if the caregiver signed these treatment
plans timely, per the requirements. Additionally, this child’s 4/24/2024-
7/24/2024 USP treatment plan was not signed by the birth parent until
11/19/2024.
• A third record showed the child’s 4/25/2024-5/23/2024 ISP treatment plan
was not signed by the birth father and birth mother until 10/18/2024 and
10/31/2024 respectively. This child’s 5/24/2024-8/21/2024 USP treatment
plan was not signed by the birth father and birth mother until 10/28/2024 and
10/31/2024 respectively.
• A fourth record showed the child’s 10/13/2023-11/11/2023 ISP treatment
plan, 11/12/2023-2/9/2024 USP treatment plan, and the child’s next two USP
treatment plans were not signed by the caregiver until 12/16/2024. This
child’s 11/12/2023-2/9/2024 USP treatment plan was not signed by the birth
father and birth mother until 9/25/2024 and 10/10/2024 respectively. This
child’s 2/10/2024-5/9/2024 USP treatment was not signed by the birth father
and birth mother until 9/25/2024 and 10/18/2024 respectively. Additionally,
the birth mother and birth father did not sign the child’s 5/10/2024-8/7/2024
USP treatment plan until 11/27/2024 and 12/16/2024 respectively.
• A fifth record did not show documentation of the caregiver’s or birth parent’s
signature on the child’s 8/2/2024-8/30/2024 ISP treatment plan.
Repeat Violation Established:
Renewal Inspection 2023, cited under FOM 722-8D, CAP approved 1/8/2024.
Interim Inspection 2022, cited under FOM 722-8D, CAP approved 2/14/2023.
CPA Rule 400.12419 Initial service plans.
(1) The initial service plan, as required in R
400.12418(2)(a), must include all the following
information:
8

(c) Assessment of the placement selection criteria as
required under R 400.12404(4).
In two of eight open foster child records reviewed the child's ISP did not show
documentation of (c) as required by the rule.
Repeat Violation Established:
Renewal Inspection 2023, CAP approved 1/8/2024.
Interim Inspection 2022, CAP approved 2/14/2023
CPA Rule 400.12419 Initial service plans
(1) The initial service plan, as required in R
400.12418(2)(a), must include all the following
information:
(h) The child behavior support plan to be used by the
foster parent.
In two of eight open foster child records reviewed the child's ISP did not show
documentation of the specific child behavior support plan to be used by the foster
parent.
Repeat Violation Established:
Renewal Inspection 2023, CAP approved 1/8/2024.
CPA Rule 400.12420 Updated service plans.
(1) An updated service plan, as required in R
400.12418(2)(b), must include all the following
information:
(g) A child behavior support plan that includes any
changes made since the previous plan and is to be used
by the foster parents.
In one of eight open foster child records reviewed the child's 11/12/2023-2/9/2024
and 2/10/2024- 5/9/2024 USP did not show documentation of the specific child
behavior support plan to be used by the foster parent.
Repeat Violation Established:
Renewal Inspection 2023, CAP approved 1/8/2024.
CPA Rule 400.12205 Required staff.
9

(8) An agency shall employ or contract for a sufficient
number of competent staff to carry out the provisions
covered by these rules. The workload for each staff
member may not be more than any of the following:
(b) Fifteen children assigned to a social services
worker for purposes of providing direct services in
foster care, independent living, adoption, or post
adoption services or a combination thereof.
Twelve of 27 direct care foster care workers had caseloads over 15. These
foster care worker’s caseloads ranged from 16 to 22.
CPA Rule 400.12327 Special evaluation.
(6) An agency shall do all the following:
(a) Provide the foster parent with a copy of the report
required by subrule (5) of this rule within 10 calendar
days of its completion.
One of seven special evaluations reviewed showed the report was not provided to
the family within 10 days of its completion.
CPA Rule 400.12417 Foster parent information.
(1) An agency shall provide a foster parent with all the
following information before the placement or
replacement of a child:
(g) Circumstances necessitating placement or
replacement of the child.
Three of eight open foster child records reviewed did not show documentation of (g)
as required by the rule. One of these records also did not show documentation of
(g), as required by the rule related to the child’s replacement on 11/8/2024.
Repeat Violation Established:
Renewal Inspection 2023, CAP approved 1/8/2024.
IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The facility was offered technical assistance in the following areas:
• R400.12327(6) (c) & (7) Special evaluation. The agency is advised its
email documentation used to document compliance to these rules shall
10

more clearly show that the worker was provided the copy of this
information.
V. CONSULTATION
The facility was offered consultation in the following areas:
• None requested or required this inspection.
VI. EVALUATION OF PERIOD UNDER REVIEW:
There were no substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during this licensing
period.
There were two incidents of substantiated corporal punishment during this licensing
period:
• The first incident related to an allegation that the foster parent punched one
foster child in the face and stomach and threw a toy at him. Additionally, that
the foster parent grabbed and slapped another foster child. During the
special evaluation one child reported the foster parent had cursed and
slapped him; the other foster child did not corroborate the allegations; but
reported the foster parent was awesome. The foster parent denied slapping
any of the children; but admitted to yelling, that she had used curse words
toward one child, and grabbed him by his shirt. Also, that and she had pulled
another child by is legs to place him gently on the floor. The foster parent
was found in noncompliance of the foster home’s behavior management
rules. A corrective action plan was completed with the foster parent that
included the foster parent completing 24 hours of Grow training as it relates to
development, attachment, prudent parenting, diversity, mental health, and
other connecting subjects.
The agency adhered all to departmental timeframes and requirements related
to this special evaluation except R400.12327 (5)(c) and R400.1237(6)(a)
where it received a citation.
• The second incident related to an allegation that during an argument with the
foster child, one of the foster parents pulled the foster child’s hood and
pushed her into a closet. The special evaluation did not substantiate that
allegation but concluded that the foster parent had yelled at the foster children
and referred to them as heifers and liars. A corrective action plan was
completed with the foster parents around training and learning appropriate
discipline techniques to use with children. The agency adhered to
departmental timeframes and requirements related to this special evaluation.
11

Corrective Action Plan Compliance
The agency has submitted one acceptable corrective action plan (CAP) during this
licensing period. This corrective action plan related to the agency’s renewal
inspection where the agency received 27 rule violations.
During this current inspection for the agency’s interim review, the agency received
21 rule violations. This was a decrease from the last inspection. Of these 21
citations, 18 are repeat violations within the last two years (16 are specific repeat
violations from the last inspection). The agency’s CAP compliance around these
16 rule violations is as follows: 3 rule violations cited showed the number of
individual cases cited stayed the same( that being 1of 8 and 2 of 8); 4 other rule
violations cited showed a decrease in the number of individual cases cited (from 4
of 8 to 1 of 8 related to 2 rules, 4 of 8 to 2 of 8 related to another rule, and 7 of 8
to 5 of 8 related to the last rule); 9 other rule violations showed a slight increase in
the number of individual cases cited( from 2 of 19 to 3 of 13 related to one of these
rules; 3 of 6 to 4 of 6 related to a second rule; 2 of 8 to 4 of 8 related to the third;
and 1 of 8 to 3 of 8 related to a fourth, fifth, sixth, seventh, eighth and nineth rule).
Electronic and or physical documents/tools were reviewed for verification of CAP
implementation and compliance. The above reporting showed that the agency,
despite the number of repeat violations, made some gains to reduce its overall
number of rule violations cited; and had some success at reducing the number of
individual cases cited by its efforts to fully implement the corrective action plan.
The number of repeat citations also show that continued work and efforts to more
fully operationalize its CAP must continue. The agency admitted an awareness of
this, and that it plans to continue its efforts.
Chief Administrator Assessment
The agency submitted a chief administrator's report dated 11/18/2024. The chief
administrator (CA) reported the agency continues to implement several strategies
in its efforts to ensure compliance with rules, policies and Act 116. These
strategies included developing spreadsheets to track due dates, along with outlook
calendar reminders. The agency also reported, utilizing Health Liaison Officers
(HLO) to assist foster care staff in obtaining medical and dental care for foster
children. The CA also reportedly that medical passports are being provided at the
time of placement and replacement; and staff are using their Book of Business,
weekly KPI (Key Performance Indicator) meetings; and that training and monthly
supervisions has aided with ensuring for proper care and placement of children,
and the timely completion of reports and social work contacts. The CA also
reported the agency has gone paperless, staff have become proficient at
uploading documents into the electronic file; and staffing groups meet monthly
with their laptops to discuss barriers, solutions, and entering missing social work
contacts.
12

Barriers that have impacted rule compliance were reported by the CA as the
agency continuing to experience staffing changes, and turnover, some due to
workers' and supervisors' medical leaves.
The CA indicated the agency has implemented the bulk of its corrective plan, and
it plans to continue utilizing all its tools and protocols to increase compliance
areas.
Financial Overview
This is not applicable. This is a Department of Health and Human Services
District office.
Staff interviews
In addition to a discussion with the chief administrator, and a number of her
management staff at the entrance conference, I interviewed two foster care
workers, a licensing worker, licensing supervisor, and foster care supervisor. The
employees interviewed reported the following as strengths of the agency: the
agency is always working to improve its compliance numbers; the agency focuses
on what needs to be done better, various supervisors and managers are good at
listening to you; and the agency tries to do things with staff appreciation. Areas
where the employees felt growth is needed, included providing more professional
development training or skill building to staff so as to aid the employee in
achieving professional advancement; supervisors being more helpful with new
worker, and or to have a mentor program for new workers similar to what the
children’s protective services program has; and having the HLOs to handle foster
children medical care needs, so as to enable foster care workers to focus on
quality time with children and families.
Description of Agency Walk Through
A walk through the of the agency's office did not reveal any concerns or safety
issues. The agency continues to have lots of office space and equipment. The
agency has gone paperless and has electronic files.
VII. FIELD ANALYST FINDINGS
There were no safety alerts reported during this licensing period.
13

VIII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the agency is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it
is recommended that the agency continue on their regular license.
January 29, 2025
________________________________________
Lonia Perry Calloway Date
Licensing Consultant
Approved By:
February 6, 2025
________________________________________
Claudia Triestram Date
Program Manager
14
